templates.name: MySQL | MariaDB
templates.description:
Template for Docker MySQL/MariaDB

Meant for use specifically with https://github.com/tiredofit/docker-mariadb > 4.0.0

items.name: MySQL: Aborted clients per second
items.description: Number of connections that were aborted because the client died without closing the connection properly.

items.name: MySQL: Aborted connections per second
items.description: Number of failed attempts to connect to the MySQL server.

triggers.name: MySQL: Server has aborted connections
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Server has aborted connections (over {$MYSQL.ABORTED_CONN.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
triggers.description: The number of failed attempts to connect to the MySQL server is more than {$MYSQL.ABORTED_CONN.MAX.WARN} in the last 5 minutes.

items.name: MySQL: Binlog cache disk use
items.description: Number of transactions that used a temporary disk cache because they could not fit in the regular binary log cache, being larger than binlog_cache_size.

items.name: MySQL: Buffer pool efficiency
items.description: The item shows how effectively the buffer pool is serving reads.

items.name: MySQL: Buffer pool utilization
items.description: Ratio of used to total pages in the buffer pool.

triggers.name: MySQL: Buffer pool utilization is too low
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Buffer pool utilization is too low (less than {$MYSQL.BUFF_UTIL.MIN.WARN}% for 5m)
triggers.description: The buffer pool utilization is less than {$MYSQL.BUFF_UTIL.MIN.WARN}% in the last 5 minutes. This means that there is a lot of unused RAM allocated for the buffer pool, which you can easily reallocate at the moment.

items.name: MySQL: Bytes received
items.description: Number of bytes received from all clients.

items.name: MySQL: Bytes sent
items.description: Number of bytes sent to all clients.

items.name: MySQL: Command Delete per second
items.description: The Com_delete counter variable indicates the number of times the delete statement has been executed.

items.name: MySQL: Command Insert per second
items.description: The Com_insert counter variable indicates the number of times the insert statement has been executed.

items.name: MySQL: Command Select per second
items.description: The Com_select counter variable indicates the number of times the select statement has been executed.

items.name: MySQL: Command Update per second
items.description: The Com_update counter variable indicates the number of times the update statement has been executed.

items.name: MySQL: Connections per second
items.description: Number of connection attempts (successful or not) to the MySQL server.

items.name: MySQL: Connection errors accept per second
items.description: Number of errors that occurred during calls to accept() on the listening port.

items.name: MySQL: Connection errors internal per second
items.description: Number of refused connections due to internal server errors, for example, out of memory errors, or failed thread starts.

items.name: MySQL: Connection errors max connections per second
items.description: Number of refused connections due to the max_connections limit being reached.

triggers.name: MySQL: Refused connections
triggers.description: Number of refused connections due to the max_connections limit being reached.

items.name: MySQL: Connection errors peer address per second
items.description: Number of errors while searching for the connecting client IP address.

items.name: MySQL: Connection errors select per second
items.description: Number of errors during calls to select() or poll() on the listening port. The client would not necessarily have been rejected in these cases.

items.name: MySQL: Connection errors tcpwrap per second
items.description: Number of connections the libwrap library has refused.

items.name: MySQL: Created tmp tables on disk per second
items.description: Number of internal on-disk temporary tables created by the server while executing statements.

triggers.name: MySQL: Number of on-disk temporary tables created per second is high
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Number of on-disk temporary tables created per second is high (over {$MYSQL.CREATED_TMP_DISK_TABLES.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
triggers.description: Possibly the application using the database is in need of query optimization.

items.name: MySQL: Created tmp files on disk per second
items.description: How many temporary files mysqld has created.

triggers.name: MySQL: Number of temporary files created per second is high
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Number of temporary files created per second is high (over {$MYSQL.CREATED_TMP_FILES.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
triggers.description: Possibly the application using the database is in need of query optimization.

items.name: MySQL: Created tmp tables on memory per second
items.description: Number of internal temporary tables created by the server while executing statements.

triggers.name: MySQL: Number of internal temporary tables created per second is high
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Number of internal temporary tables created per second is high (over {$MYSQL.CREATED_TMP_TABLES.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
triggers.description: Possibly the application using the database is in need of query optimization.

items.name: MySQL: Get status variables
items.description: The item gets server global status information.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool pages free
items.description: The total size of the InnoDB buffer pool, in pages.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool pages total
items.description: The total size of the InnoDB buffer pool, in pages.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool reads
items.description: Number of logical reads that InnoDB could not satisfy from the buffer pool, and had to read directly from the disk.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool reads per second
items.description: Number of logical reads per second that InnoDB could not satisfy from the buffer pool, and had to read directly from the disk.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool read requests
items.description: Number of logical read requests.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool read requests per second
items.description: Number of logical read requests per second.

items.name: MySQL: Innodb buffer pool wait free
items.description: Number of times InnoDB waited for a free page before reading or creating a page. Normally, writes to the InnoDB buffer pool happen in the background. When no clean pages are available, dirty pages are flushed first in order to free some up. This counts the numbers of wait for this operation to finish. If this value is not small, look at the increasing innodb_buffer_pool_size.

items.name: MySQL: Calculated value of innodb_log_file_size
items.description: Calculated by (innodb_os_log_written-innodb_os_log_written(time shift -1h))/{$MYSQL.INNODB_LOG_FILES} value of the innodb_log_file_size. Innodb_log_file_size is the size in bytes of the each InnoDB redo log file in the log group. The combined size can be no more than 512GB. Larger values mean less disk I/O due to less flushing checkpoint activity, but also slower recovery from a crash.

items.name: MySQL: Innodb number open files
items.description: Number of open files held by InnoDB. InnoDB only.

items.name: MySQL: Innodb log written
items.description: Number of bytes written to the InnoDB log.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB row lock time
items.description: The total time spent in acquiring row locks for InnoDB tables, in milliseconds.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB row lock time max
items.description: The maximum time to acquire a row lock for InnoDB tables, in milliseconds.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB row lock waits
items.description: Number of times operations on InnoDB tables had to wait for a row lock.

items.name: MySQL: Max used connections
items.description: The maximum number of connections that have been in use simultaneously since the server start.

items.name: MySQL: Open tables
items.description: Number of tables that are open.

items.name: MySQL: Open table definitions
items.description: Number of cached table definitions.

items.name: MySQL: Queries per second
items.description: Number of statements executed by the server. This variable includes statements executed within stored programs, unlike the Questions variable.

items.name: MySQL: Questions per second
items.description: Number of statements executed by the server. This includes only statements sent to the server by clients and not statements executed within stored programs, unlike the Queries variable.

items.name: MySQL: Slow queries per second
items.description: Number of queries that have taken more than long_query_time seconds.

triggers.name: MySQL: Server has slow queries
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Server has slow queries (over {$MYSQL.SLOW_QUERIES.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
triggers.description: The number of slow queries is more than {$MYSQL.SLOW_QUERIES.MAX.WARN} in the last 5 minutes.

items.name: MySQL: Threads cached
items.description: Number of threads in the thread cache.

items.name: MySQL: Threads connected
items.description: Number of currently open connections.

items.name: MySQL: Threads created per second
items.description: Number of threads created to handle connections. If Threads_created is big, you may want to increase the thread_cache_size value. The cache miss rate can be calculated as Threads_created/Connections.

items.name: MySQL: Threads running
items.description: Number of threads which are not sleeping.

items.name: MySQL: Uptime
items.description: The amount of seconds that the server has been up.

triggers.name: MySQL: Failed to fetch info data
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Failed to fetch info data (or no data for 30m)
triggers.description: Zabbix has not received data for items for the last 30 minutes.

triggers.name: MySQL: Service has been restarted
triggers.description: MySQL uptime is less than 10 minutes.

triggers.name: MySQL: Version has changed
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Version has changed (new version value received: {ITEM.VALUE})
triggers.description: MySQL version has changed. Ack to close.

discovery_rules.name: MariaDB discovery
discovery_rules.description: Additional metrics if MariaDB is used.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Binlog commits
item_prototypes.description: Total number of transactions committed to the binary log.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Binlog group commits
item_prototypes.description: Total number of group commits done to the binary log.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Master GTID wait count
item_prototypes.description: The number of times MASTER_GTID_WAIT called.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Master GTID wait timeouts
item_prototypes.description: Number of timeouts occurring in MASTER_GTID_WAIT.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Master GTID wait time
item_prototypes.description: Total number of time spent in MASTER_GTID_WAIT.

discovery_rules.name: Replication discovery
discovery_rules.description: If "show slave status" returns Master_Host, "Replication: *" items are created.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Replication Slave status {#MASTER_HOST}
item_prototypes.description: The item gets status information on the essential parameters of the slave threads.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Replication Seconds Behind Master {#MASTER_HOST}
item_prototypes.description:
Number of seconds that the slave SQL thread is behind processing the master binary log.
A high number (or an increasing one) can indicate that the slave is unable to handle events
from the master in a timely fashion.

trigger_prototypes.name: MySQL: Replication lag is too high
trigger_prototypes.event_name: MySQL: Replication lag is too high (over {$MYSQL.REPL_LAG.MAX.WARN} for 5m)

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Replication Slave IO Running {#MASTER_HOST}
item_prototypes.description:
Whether the I/O thread for reading the master's binary log is running.
Normally, you want this to be Yes unless you have not yet started a replication or have
explicitly stopped it with STOP SLAVE.

trigger_prototypes.name: MySQL: The slave I/O thread is not connected to a replication master

dependencies.name: MySQL: The slave I/O thread is not running

trigger_prototypes.name: MySQL: The slave I/O thread is not running
trigger_prototypes.description: Whether the I/O thread for reading the master's binary log is running.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Replication Slave SQL Running {#MASTER_HOST}
item_prototypes.description:
Whether the SQL thread for executing events in the relay log is running.
As with the I/O thread, this should normally be Yes.

trigger_prototypes.name: MySQL: The SQL thread is not running
trigger_prototypes.description: Whether the SQL thread for executing events in the relay log is running.

dependencies.name: MySQL: The slave I/O thread is not running

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Replication Slave SQL Running State {#MASTER_HOST}
item_prototypes.description: This shows the state of the SQL driver threads.

macros.description: Number of failed attempts to connect to the MySQL server for trigger expression.
The minimum buffer pool utilization percentage for trigger expression.
The maximum number of created tmp tables on a disk per second for trigger expressions.
The maximum number of created tmp files on a disk per second for trigger expressions.
The maximum number of created tmp tables in memory per second for trigger expressions.
This selects the session from the Docker Image, leave as toi
Number of physical files in the InnoDB redo log for calculating innodb_log_file_size.
Password is already filled in via Docker Image - Leave Blank
The lag of slave from master for trigger expression.
The number of slow queries for trigger expression.
Username is already filled in via Docker Image - Leave Blank
